text: hey everybody thomas joseph here with a
holiday conundrum for you all the
centerpiece of the table is of course
your holiday roast and in front of me I
have a pork roast but so many people
across the nation they have different
types of roast that they feature on
their holiday table maybe it's a turkey
breast or a beef tenderloin or a beef
rib roast the roasts are kind of endless
but the technique is all the same and
there are a few steps along the way that
you need to know to have a very
successful holiday roast and I'm going
to show you that today the number one
thing is to dry brine or season your
meat in advance because what this does
is it helps the seasoning penetrate into
the meat giving you a really flavorful
roast and for this brine I'm just going
to use a simple combination of kosher
salt some freshly ground black pepper
it's very important to grind your pepper
right before you use it so that it has
that spice in that heat and I'm going to
add some rosemary but this is all
interchangeable you can use rosemary you
can use sage you can use any of those
woodsy herbs I'm just going to pick it
and kind of put it into the salt and
pepper mixture you could use lemon zest
any citrus zest would be absolutely
delicious so I'm just going to mix this
together with my hands and then
liberally sprinkle your mixture over
your roast and then just take your hands
and kind of work the salt into and
around all sides and you really have to
be generous here because you want this
mixture to really penetrate into the
meat and give you a really flavorful
roast now this is a five pound pork
roast and this will dry brine overnight
or up to 24 hours if you are using
something smaller like a turkey breast
that should only go for maybe six to
eight hours and if you're doing
something as big as a rib roast and this
is a seven pound rib roast here that is
something that could take up to two days
to brine so this is going to go into the
refrigerator now the brining method is
all the same but the length of time
depends on the size of the meat so dry
brining that's the first step in
successful roasting the second is making
sure that the meat you have is brought
to room temp
before you start the cooking process so
our roast it's been in the refrigerator
overnight I'm going to take the dry
brine off and just kind of use a paper
towel to gently brush off any excess if
you're roasting a turkey or if you're
roasting another big cut of meat
sometimes it's helpful to actually rinse
off the brine so now you'll notice that
I had the pork roast tied and what that
is trussing that's what it's called when
you trust together your roast it keeps
it in a nice compact even shape which
promotes even cooking so make sure that
you ask your butcher to trust it or you
should learn how to trust it yourself
I'm going to add a little bit of oil
around the roast so remember this roast
is at room temperature it's been out of
the refrigerator for at least two hours
so it's not icy cold when it goes into
the pan if it was icy cold what would
happen is the extra of the roast would
cook too quickly and get dry and crumbly
and the interior wouldn't have a chance
to cook just goes into a preheated pan
to start off the caramelization or the
crust of the roast so our pork roast has
been searing on just one side and if you
were doing something bigger like a
turkey or if you were doing this prime
rib roast here you could do this step in
the oven at a high high temperature like
a 450 degrees in math which gives a
wonderful crust to the exterior so this
looks good and I just want to sear this
on all sides before I put it into an
oven I have my oven preheating to 375
degrees to finish cooking the roast
completely our roast is nicely browned
and that is our third step so searing is
the third step I'm just going to remove
the roast to a pan here and I'm going to
place a wire rack in the bottom of my
roasting pan now you can use a classic
roasting pan if you need it for
something big like a turkey or a rib
roast this is perfect for the pork roast
that I'm using the rack really helps to
encourage even cooking so the airflow
gets underneath the roast it gets on top
of the roast and around the roast and it
cooks evenly and it Browns
at a nice even rate - so this is going
into the oven at 375 to finish cooking
the Rose has been in the oven for an
hour and a half and I'm temping it right
in the center of the meat you want to
make sure you use an instant-read
thermometer and instead of going
directly in overhead you go in from the
side into the thickest part of the meat
and it should register for pork about
135 and what will happen over time
resting which is the important number
five step is that carryover cooking will
happen and so anywhere from five to ten
degrees your roast will go up wallet
breast so I'm going to remove this from
the pan so it doesn't keep cooking in
that hot pan place it onto your carving
board and rest it for at least 20
minutes for a roast the size anywhere up
to 20 to 30 minutes and to keep it nice
and warm so it doesn't get too cold you
can cover or tent loosely with some
aluminum foil our roast has been resting
for about 20 minutes and now I'm just
going to remove the strings and now to
carve the roast you don't want to give
too big of piece I would say a quarter
of an inch slice is very nice for this
pork roast
you can see how wonderfully moist it is
now remember those steps we first we dry
brined the second step bringing the
roast up to room temperature before
cooking our third step searing the meat
and then roasting of course at a lower
temperature 375 and then of course
resting so that all of those wonderful
juices stay inside your meat so there
you have it the five steps for mastering
your holiday roast enjoy
